**Saint Paul** (abbreviated **St. Paul**) is the
[capital](/wiki/List_of_capitals_in_the_United_States "List of capitals in the
United States") and second-most populous city of the [U.S.
state](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state") of [Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota
"Minnesota"). As of 2016, the city's estimated population was 304,442.[5]
Saint Paul is the [county seat](/wiki/County_seat "County seat") of [Ramsey
County](/wiki/Ramsey_County,_Minnesota "Ramsey County, Minnesota"), the
smallest and most densely populated county in Minnesota.[6] The city lies
mostly on the east bank of the [Mississippi River](/wiki/Mississippi_River
"Mississippi River") in the area surrounding its point of confluence with the
[Minnesota River](/wiki/Minnesota_River "Minnesota River"), and adjoins
[Minneapolis](/wiki/Minneapolis "Minneapolis"), the state's [largest
city](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Minnesota "List of cities in Minnesota"). Known
as the "Twin Cities", the two form the core of [Minneapolis–Saint
Paul](/wiki/Minneapolis%E2%80%93Saint_Paul "Minneapolis–Saint Paul"), the
16th-largest [metropolitan
area](/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_of_the_United_States "List of
metropolitan areas of the United States") in the United States, with about
3.52 million residents.[7]

Founded near historic Native American settlements as a trading and
transportation center, the city rose to prominence when it was named the
capital of the [Minnesota Territory](/wiki/Minnesota_Territory "Minnesota
Territory") in 1849. The Dakota name for Saint Paul is "Imnizaska". Though
Minneapolis (Bdeota) is better-known nationally, Saint Paul contains the state
government and other important institutions.[8] Regionally, the city is known
for the [Xcel Energy Center](/wiki/Xcel_Energy_Center "Xcel Energy Center"),
home of the [Minnesota Wild](/wiki/Minnesota_Wild "Minnesota Wild"),[9] and
for the [Science Museum of Minnesota](/wiki/Science_Museum_of_Minnesota
"Science Museum of Minnesota").[10][11] As a business hub of the [Upper
Midwest](/wiki/Upper_Midwest "Upper Midwest"), it is the headquarters of
companies such as [Ecolab](/wiki/Ecolab "Ecolab").[12] Saint Paul, along with
its Twin City, Minneapolis, is known for its high literacy rate. It was the
only city in the United States with a population of 250,000 or more to see an
increase in circulation of Sunday newspapers in 2007.[13]

The settlement originally began at present-day Lambert's Landing, but was
known as Pig's Eye after [Pierre "Pig's Eye" Parrant](/wiki/Pierre_Parrant
"Pierre Parrant") established a popular tavern there. When [Lucien
Galtier](/wiki/Lucien_Galtier "Lucien Galtier"), the first Catholic pastor of
the region, established the Log Chapel of Saint Paul (shortly thereafter to
become the first location of the [Cathedral of Saint
Paul](/wiki/Cathedral_of_Saint_Paul_in_Saint_Paul "Cathedral of Saint Paul in
Saint Paul")), he made it known that the settlement was now to be called by
that name, as "Saint Paul as applied to a town or city was well appropriated,
this monosyllable is short, sounds good, it is understood by all Christian
denominations".[14]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Paul,_Minnesota&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

Main article: [History of Saint Paul,
Minnesota](/wiki/History_of_Saint_Paul,_Minnesota "History of Saint Paul,
Minnesota")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Indian_Mounds_park.jpg/220px-
Indian_Mounds_park.jpg)](/wiki/File:Indian_Mounds_park.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Indian_Mounds_park.jpg "Enlarge")

A burial mound at [Indian Mounds
Park](/wiki/Indian_Mounds_Park_\(Saint_Paul,_Minnesota\) "Indian Mounds Park
\(Saint Paul, Minnesota\)")

Burial mounds in present-day [Indian Mounds
Park](/wiki/Indian_Mounds_Park_\(Saint_Paul,_Minnesota\) "Indian Mounds Park
\(Saint Paul, Minnesota\)") suggest that the area was originally inhabited by
the [Hopewell](/wiki/Hopewell_tradition "Hopewell tradition") Native Americans
about two thousand years ago.[15][16] From the early 17th century until 1837,
the [Mdewakanton Dakota](/wiki/Mdewakanton "Mdewakanton"), a tribe of the
[Sioux](/wiki/Sioux "Sioux"), lived near the mounds after fleeing their
ancestral home of [Mille Lacs Lake](/wiki/Mille_Lacs_Lake "Mille Lacs Lake")
from advancing [Ojibwe](/wiki/Ojibwe "Ojibwe").[15][17] They called the area
_I-mni-za ska dan_ ("little white rock") for its exposed white sandstone
cliffs.[18][19]

Following the [Louisiana Purchase](/wiki/Louisiana_Purchase "Louisiana
Purchase") in 1803, US Army officer [Zebulon Pike](/wiki/Zebulon_Pike "Zebulon
Pike") negotiated approximately 100,000 acres (40,000 ha; 160 sq mi) of land
from the local Dakota tribes in 1805 to establish a fort. The negotiated
territory was located on both banks of the Mississippi River, starting from
[Saint Anthony Falls](/wiki/Saint_Anthony_Falls "Saint Anthony Falls") in
present-day Minneapolis, to its confluence with the [Saint Croix
River](/wiki/St._Croix_River_\(Wisconsin-Minnesota\) "St. Croix River
\(Wisconsin-Minnesota\)").[20] [Fort Snelling](/wiki/Fort_Snelling "Fort
Snelling") was built on the territory in 1819 at the confluence of the
Mississippi and [Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota_River "Minnesota River") rivers,
which formed a natural barrier to both Native American nations. The 1837
Treaty with the Sioux ceded all local tribal land east of the Mississippi to
the U.S. Government.[21] [Taoyateduta](/wiki/Taoyateduta "Taoyateduta") (Chief
Little Crow V) moved his band at [Kaposia](/wiki/Kaposia "Kaposia") across the
river to the south.[22][23] Fur traders, explorers, and missionaries came to
the area for the fort's protection. Many of the settlers were French-Canadians
who lived nearby. However, as a whiskey trade flourished, military officers
banned settlers from the fort-controlled lands. [Pierre "Pig's Eye"
Parrant](/wiki/Pierre_Parrant "Pierre Parrant"), a retired fur trader-
turned-[bootlegger](/wiki/Rum-running "Rum-running") who particularly
irritated officials,[24] set up his tavern, the Pig's Eye, near present-day
Lambert's Landing.[19] By the early 1840s, the community had become important
as a trading center and a destination for settlers heading west. Locals called
the area _Pig 's Eye_ (French: _L 'Œil du Cochon_) or _Pig 's Eye Landing_
after Parrant's popular tavern.[24]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Joseph_Rolette_c1841.jpg/220px-
Joseph_Rolette_c1841.jpg)](/wiki/File:Joseph_Rolette_c1841.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Joseph_Rolette_c1841.jpg "Enlarge")

[Joe Rolette](/wiki/Joe_Rolette "Joe Rolette") was responsible for preventing
the capital of Minnesota from moving to [Saint
Peter](/wiki/Saint_Peter,_Minnesota "Saint Peter, Minnesota").

In 1841, Father Lucien Galtier was sent to minister to the Catholic French
Canadians and established a chapel, named for his favorite saint, [Paul the
Apostle](/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle "Paul the Apostle"), on the bluffs above
Lambert's Landing.[25][26] Galtier intended for the settlement to adopt the
name Saint Paul in honor of the new chapel.[24] In 1847, a New York educator
named [Harriet Bishop](/wiki/Harriet_Bishop "Harriet Bishop") moved to the
area and opened the city's first school.[27] The [Minnesota
Territory](/wiki/Minnesota_Territory "Minnesota Territory") was formalized in
1849 and Saint Paul named as its capital. In 1857, the territorial legislature
voted to move the capital to [Saint Peter](/wiki/Saint_Peter,_Minnesota "Saint
Peter, Minnesota"). However, [Joe Rolette](/wiki/Joe_Rolette "Joe Rolette"), a
territorial legislator, stole the physical text of the approved bill and went
into hiding, thus preventing the move.[28] On May 11, 1858, Minnesota was
admitted to the union as the thirty-second state, with Saint Paul as the
capital.

That year, more than 1,000 steamboats were in service at Saint Paul,[27]
making the city a gateway for settlers to the Minnesota frontier or Dakota
Territory. Natural geography was a primary reason that the city became a
landing. The area was the last accessible point to unload boats coming upriver
due to the Mississippi River Valley's stone bluffs. During this period, Saint
Paul was called "The Last City of the East."[29] Industrialist [James J.
Hill](/wiki/James_J._Hill "James J. Hill") constructed and expanded his
network of railways into the [Great Northern
Railway](/wiki/Great_Northern_Railway_\(U.S.\) "Great Northern Railway
\(U.S.\)") and [Northern Pacific Railway](/wiki/Northern_Pacific_Railway
"Northern Pacific Railway"), which were headquartered in Saint Paul. Today
they are collectively part of the [BNSF Railway](/wiki/BNSF_Railway "BNSF
Railway").[29]

On August 20, 1904, severe [thunderstorms](/wiki/Thunderstorm "Thunderstorm")
and [tornadoes](/wiki/Tornado "Tornado") damaged hundreds of downtown
buildings, causing [USD](/wiki/USD "USD") $1.78 million ($48.48 million
present-day) in damages to the city and ripping spans from the [High
Bridge](/wiki/High_Bridge_\(St._Paul\) "High Bridge \(St. Paul\)").[30] In the
1960s, during [urban renewal](/wiki/Urban_renewal "Urban renewal"), Saint Paul
razed western neighborhoods close to downtown. The city also contended with
the creation of the interstate freeway system in a fully built landscape.[31]
From 1959 to 1961, the western [Rondo Neighborhood](/wiki/Rondo_Neighborhood
"Rondo Neighborhood") was demolished by the construction of [Interstate
94](/wiki/Interstate_94_in_Minnesota "Interstate 94 in Minnesota"), which
brought attention to racial segregation and unequal housing in northern
cities.[32] The annual [Rondo Days](/wiki/Rondo_Days "Rondo Days") celebration
commemorates the African American community.[33]

Downtown had short skyscraper-building booms beginning in the 1970s. The
tallest buildings, such as [Galtier Plaza](/wiki/Galtier_Plaza "Galtier
Plaza") (Jackson and Sibley Towers), The Pointe of Saint Paul condominiums,
and the city's tallest building, [Wells Fargo Place](/wiki/Wells_Fargo_Place
"Wells Fargo Place") (formerly Minnesota World Trade Center), were constructed
in the late 1980s.[34] In the 1990s and 2000s, the tradition of bringing new
immigrant groups to the city continued. As of 2004, nearly 10% of the city's
population were recent [Hmong](/wiki/Hmong_people "Hmong people") immigrants
from [Vietnam](/wiki/Vietnam "Vietnam"), [Laos](/wiki/Laos "Laos"),
[Cambodia](/wiki/Cambodia "Cambodia"), [Thailand](/wiki/Thailand "Thailand"),
and [Myanmar](/wiki/Myanmar "Myanmar").[35] Saint Paul is the location of the
[Hmong Archives](/wiki/Hmong_Archives "Hmong Archives").[36]

##
Geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Paul,_Minnesota&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Geography")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Meeker_Island_Lock_and_Dam.jpg/220px-
Meeker_Island_Lock_and_Dam.jpg)](/wiki/File:Meeker_Island_Lock_and_Dam.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Meeker_Island_Lock_and_Dam.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Meeker Island](/wiki/Meeker_Island "Meeker Island") Lock and Dam was the
first lock and dam on the Mississippi River in 1902.

Saint Paul's history and growth as a landing port are tied to water. The
city's defining physical characteristic, the confluence of the Mississippi and
Minnesota Rivers, was carved into the region during the [last ice
age](/wiki/Wisconsin_glaciation "Wisconsin glaciation"), as were the steep
river bluffs and dramatic palisades on which the city is built. Receding
[glaciers](/wiki/Glacier "Glacier") and [Lake Agassiz](/wiki/Lake_Agassiz
"Lake Agassiz") forced torrents of water from a [glacial
river](/wiki/Glacial_River_Warren "Glacial River Warren") that undercut the
river valleys.[37] The city is situated in east-central Minnesota.

The Mississippi River forms a municipal boundary on part of the city's west,
southwest, and southeast sides. [Minneapolis](/wiki/Minneapolis
"Minneapolis"), the state's largest city, lies to the west. [Falcon
Heights](/wiki/Falcon_Heights,_Minnesota "Falcon Heights, Minnesota"),
[Lauderdale](/wiki/Lauderdale,_Minnesota "Lauderdale, Minnesota"),
[Roseville](/wiki/Roseville,_Minnesota "Roseville, Minnesota"), and
[Maplewood](/wiki/Maplewood,_Minnesota "Maplewood, Minnesota") are north, with
Maplewood lying to the east. The cities of [West Saint
Paul](/wiki/West_St._Paul,_Minnesota "West St. Paul, Minnesota") and [South
Saint Paul](/wiki/South_Saint_Paul "South Saint Paul") are to the south, as
are [Lilydale](/wiki/Lilydale,_Minnesota "Lilydale, Minnesota"),
[Mendota](/wiki/Mendota,_Minnesota "Mendota, Minnesota"), and [Mendota
Heights](/wiki/Mendota_Heights "Mendota Heights"), although across the river
from the city. The city's largest lakes are Pig's Eye Lake, which is part of
the Mississippi, [Lake Phalen](/wiki/Lake_Phalen "Lake Phalen"), and [Lake
Como](/wiki/Lake_Como_\(Minnesota\) "Lake Como \(Minnesota\)"). According to
the [United States Census Bureau](/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau "United
States Census Bureau"), the city has a total area of 56.18 square miles
(145.51 km2), of which 51.98 square miles (134.63 km2) is land and 4.20 square
miles (10.88 km2) is water.[1]

###
Neighborhoods[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Paul,_Minnesota&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Neighborhoods")]

Main article: [Neighborhoods of Saint Paul](/wiki/Neighborhoods_of_Saint_Paul
"Neighborhoods of Saint Paul")

Saint Paul's Department of Planning and Economic Development divides Saint
Paul into seventeen Planning Districts, created in 1979 to allow neighborhoods
to participate in governance and use [Community Development Block
Grants](/wiki/Community_Development_Block_Grant "Community Development Block
Grant"). With a funding agreement directly from the city, the councils share a
pool of funds.[38] The councils have significant land-use control, a voice in
guiding development, and they organize residents.[39] The boundaries are
adjusted depending on population changes; as such, they sometimes overlap
established neighborhoods.[40] Though these neighborhoods changed over time,
preservationists have saved many of their historically significant structures.

The city's seventeen Planning Districts are:

  1. Sunray-Battle Creek-Highwood
  2. Greater East Side
  3. West Side
  4. Dayton's Bluff
  5. Payne-Phalen
  6. North End
  7. Thomas Dale ([Frogtown](/wiki/Frogtown "Frogtown"))
  8. Summit-University
  9. [West End](/wiki/West_Seventh,_Saint_Paul "West Seventh, Saint Paul")
  10. [Como Park](/wiki/Como_Park,_Zoo,_and_Conservatory "Como Park, Zoo, and Conservatory")
  11. Hamline-Midway
  12. [Saint Anthony Park](/wiki/Saint_Anthony_Park_\(Saint_Paul\) "Saint Anthony Park \(Saint Paul\)")
  13. Union Park
  14. Macalester-Groveland
  15. [Highland Park](/wiki/Highland_Park,_Saint_Paul "Highland Park, Saint Paul")
  16. [Summit Hill](/wiki/Summit_Avenue_\(St._Paul\) "Summit Avenue \(St. Paul\)")
  17. [Downtown](/wiki/Downtown_Saint_Paul "Downtown Saint Paul")

###
Climate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Paul,_Minnesota&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Climate")]

See also: [Climate of the Twin Cities](/wiki/Climate_of_the_Twin_Cities
"Climate of the Twin Cities") and [Climate of
Minnesota](/wiki/Climate_of_Minnesota "Climate of Minnesota")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Saint_paul_mn.jpg/220px-
Saint_paul_mn.jpg)](/wiki/File:Saint_paul_mn.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Saint_paul_mn.jpg "Enlarge")

The city skyline from the southwest in the winter

Saint Paul has a [continental climate](/wiki/Continental_climate "Continental
climate") typical of the [Upper Midwestern United States](/wiki/Upper_Midwest
"Upper Midwest"). Winters are frigid and snowy, while summers are warm to hot
and humid. On the [Köppen climate
classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate
classification"), Saint Paul falls in the hot summer [humid continental
climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") zone
(_Dfa_). The city experiences a full range of precipitation and related
weather events, including snow, [sleet](/wiki/Rain_and_snow_mixed "Rain and
snow mixed"), ice, rain, [thunderstorms](/wiki/Thunderstorm "Thunderstorm"),
[tornadoes](/wiki/Tornado "Tornado"), and [fog](/wiki/Fog "Fog").[41]

Due to its northerly location in the United States and lack of large bodies of
water to moderate the air, Saint Paul is sometimes subjected to cold Arctic
[air masses](/wiki/Air_mass "Air mass"), especially during late December,
January, and February. The average annual temperature of 47.05 °F (8.36 °C)
gives the Minneapolis−Saint Paul metropolitan area the coldest annual mean
temperature of any major metropolitan area in the [continental
U.S.](/wiki/Continental_U.S. "Continental U.S.")[42]

The earliest known inhabitants from about 400 A.D. were members of the
[Hopewell tradition](/wiki/Hopewell_tradition "Hopewell tradition") who buried
their dead in mounds (now [Indian Mounds
Park](/wiki/Indian_Mounds_Park_\(Saint_Paul,_Minnesota\) "Indian Mounds Park
\(Saint Paul, Minnesota\)")) on the bluffs above the river. The next known
inhabitants were the [Mdewakanton](/wiki/Mdewakanton "Mdewakanton")
[Dakota](/wiki/Sioux "Sioux") in the 17th century who fled their ancestral
home of [Mille Lacs Lake](/wiki/Mille_Lacs_Lake "Mille Lacs Lake") in central
Minnesota in response to westward expansion of the [Ojibwe](/wiki/Ojibwa
"Ojibwa") nation.[17] The Ojibwe would later occupy the north (east) bank of
the Mississippi River.

By 1800, [French-Canadian](/wiki/French-Canadian "French-Canadian") explorers
came through the region and attracted fur traders to the area. [Fort
Snelling](/wiki/Fort_Snelling "Fort Snelling") and nearby Pig's Eye Tavern
also brought the first Yankees from [New England](/wiki/New_England "New
England") and [English](/wiki/English_people "English people"),
[Irish](/wiki/Irish_people "Irish people"), and
[Scottish](/wiki/Scottish_people "Scottish people")
[immigrants](/wiki/Immigrant "Immigrant") who had enlisted in the army and
settled nearby after discharge. These early settlers and entrepreneurs built
houses on the heights north of the river. The first wave of immigration came
with the Irish who settled at [Connemara Patch](/wiki/Connemara_Patch
"Connemara Patch") along the Mississippi, named for their home in
[Connemara](/wiki/Connemara "Connemara") Ireland. The Irish would [become
prolific](/wiki/History_of_the_Irish_in_Saint_Paul "History of the Irish in
Saint Paul") in politics, city governance, and public safety, much to the
chagrin of the Germans and French who had grown into the majority. In 1850,
the first of many groups of [Swedish immigrants](/wiki/Swedish_people "Swedish
people") passed through Saint Paul on their way to farming communities in
northern and western regions of the [territory](/wiki/Minnesota_Territory
"Minnesota Territory"). A large group settled in [Swede
Hollow](/wiki/Swede_Hollow "Swede Hollow"), which would later become home to
Poles, Italians, and Mexicans. The last Swedish presence had moved up Saint
Paul's East Side along [Payne Avenue](/wiki/Payne_Avenue_State_Bank "Payne
Avenue State Bank") in the 1950s.[51]

In terms of people who specified [European ancestry](/wiki/European_American
"European American") in the 2005-2007 [American Community
Survey](/wiki/American_Community_Survey "American Community Survey"), the city
was 26.4% [German](/wiki/German_American "German American"), 13.8%
[Irish](/wiki/Irish_American "Irish American"), 8.4%
[Norwegian](/wiki/Norwegian_American "Norwegian American"), 7.0%
[Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_American "Swedish American"), and 6.2%
[English](/wiki/English_American "English American"). There is also a visible
community of people of [Sub-Saharan African](/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa "Sub-
Saharan Africa") ancestry, representing 4.2% of Saint Paul's population. By
the 1980s, the Thomas Dale area, once an Austro-Hungarian enclave known as
[Frogtown](/wiki/Frogtown "Frogtown") (German: _Froschburg_), became home to
Vietnamese people who left their war-torn country. Soon after a settlement
program for the Hmong diaspora came, and by 2000, the Saint Paul Hmong were
the largest urban contingent in the United States.[52][53][54] Mexican
immigrants have settled in Saint Paul's West Side since the 1930s, and have
grown enough that Mexico opened a foreign consulate in 2005.[55][56]

The majority of residents claiming religious affiliation are
[Christian](/wiki/Christian "Christian"), split between the [Roman Catholic
Church](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church "Roman Catholic Church") and various
[Protestant](/wiki/Protestant "Protestant") denominations. The Roman Catholic
presence comes from Irish, German, Scottish, and French Canadian settlers who,
in time, would be bolstered by Hispanic immigrants. There are
[Jewish](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism") [synagogues](/wiki/Synagogue "Synagogue")
such as [Mount Zion Temple](/wiki/Mount_Zion_Temple "Mount Zion Temple") and
relatively small populations of [Hindus](/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism"),
[Muslims](/wiki/Islam "Islam"), and [Buddhists](/wiki/Buddhism
"Buddhism").[57] The city has been dubbed "paganistan" due to its large
[Wiccan](/wiki/Wicca "Wicca") population.[58]

As of the 2005-2007 [American Community
Survey](/wiki/American_Community_Survey "American Community Survey") conducted
by the [U.S. Census Bureau](/wiki/U.S._Census_Bureau "U.S. Census Bureau"),
[White Americans](/wiki/White_American "White American") made up 66.5% of
Saint Paul's population; of which 62.1% were non-Hispanic [whites](/wiki/Non-
Hispanic_Whites "Non-Hispanic Whites"), down from 93.6% in 1970.[49]
[Blacks](/wiki/Black_people "Black people") or [African
Americans](/wiki/African_American "African American") made up 13.9% of Saint
Paul's population; of which 13.5% were non-Hispanic blacks. [American
Indians](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous peoples of the
Americas") made up 0.8% of Saint Paul's population; of which 0.6% were non-
Hispanic. [Asian Americans](/wiki/Asian_American "Asian American") made up
12.3% of Saint Paul's population; of which 12.2% were non-Hispanic. [Pacific
Islander Americans](/wiki/Pacific_Islander_American "Pacific Islander
American") made up less than 0.1% of Saint Paul's population. Individuals from
some other race made up 3.4% of Saint Paul's population; of which 0.2% were
non-Hispanic. Individuals from [two or more races](/wiki/Multiracial_American
"Multiracial American") made up 3.1% of Saint Paul's population; of which 2.6%
were non-Hispanic. In addition, [Hispanics and
Latinos](/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans "Hispanic and Latino Americans")
made up 8.7% of Saint Paul's population.

As of the [2000 U.S. Census](/wiki/2000_United_States_Census "2000 United
States Census"),[59] there were 287,151 people, 112,109 households, and 60,999
families residing in the city. The racial makeup of the city was 67.0%
[White](/wiki/White_\(U.S._Census\) "White \(U.S. Census\)"), 11.7% [African
American](/wiki/African_American_\(U.S._Census\) "African American \(U.S.
Census\)"), 1.1% [Native American](/wiki/Native_American_\(U.S._Census\)
"Native American \(U.S. Census\)"), 12.4% [Asian](/wiki/Asian_\(U.S._Census\)
"Asian \(U.S. Census\)") (mostly [Hmong](/wiki/Hmong_American "Hmong
American")), 0.1% [Pacific Islander](/wiki/Pacific_Islander_\(U.S._Census\)
"Pacific Islander \(U.S. Census\)"), 3.8% from [other
races](/wiki/Race_\(United_States_Census\) "Race \(United States Census\)"),
and 3.9% from two or more races. [Hispanic](/wiki/Hispanic_\(U.S._Census\)
"Hispanic \(U.S. Census\)") or [Latino](/wiki/Latino_\(U.S._Census\) "Latino
\(U.S. Census\)") of any race were 7.9% of the population.

### 2010
census[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Paul,_Minnesota&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: 2010 census")]

As of the [census](/wiki/Census "Census")[2] of 2010, there were 285,068
people, 111,001 households, and 59,689 families residing in the city. The
[population density](/wiki/Population_density "Population density") was
5,484.2 inhabitants per square mile (2,117.5/km2). There were 120,795 housing
units at an average density of 2,323.9 per square mile (897.3/km2). The racial
makeup of the city was 60.1% white, 15.7% African American, 1.1% Native
American, 15.0% Asian, 0.1% [Pacific Islander](/wiki/Race_\(U.S._Census\)
"Race \(U.S. Census\)"), 3.9% from other races, and 4.2% from two or more
races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 9.6% of the population.

There were 111,001 households of which 30.4% had children under the age of 18
living with them, 34.1% were [married couples](/wiki/Marriage "Marriage")
living together, 14.8% had a female householder with no husband present, 4.9%
had a male householder with no wife present, and 46.2% were non-families.
35.8% of all households were made up of individuals and 8.5% had someone
living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was
2.47 and the average family size was 3.33.

The median age in the city was 30.9 years. 25.1% of residents were under the
age of 18; 13.9% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 29.6% were from 25 to 44;
22.6% were from 45 to 64; and 9% were 65 years of age or older. The gender
makeup of the city was 48.9% male and 51.1% female.

##
Economy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Paul,_Minnesota&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Economy")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/MN_Ford_plant.jpg/220px-
MN_Ford_plant.jpg)](/wiki/File:MN_Ford_plant.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MN_Ford_plant.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Ford Motor Company](/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company "Ford Motor Company")'s
[Twin Cities Assembly Plant](/wiki/Twin_Cities_Assembly_Plant "Twin Cities
Assembly Plant") in 2006

The Minneapolis–Saint Paul–Bloomington area employs 1,570,700 people in the
private sector as of July 2008, 82.43 percent of which work in private service
providing-related jobs.[60]

Major [corporations](/wiki/Corporation "Corporation") headquartered in Saint
Paul include [Ecolab](/wiki/Ecolab "Ecolab"), a chemical and cleaning product
company[61] which was named in 2008 by the _Minneapolis / St. Paul Business
Journal_ as the eighth best place to work in the Twin Cites for companies with
1,000 full-time Minnesota employees,[62] and [Securian Financial Group
Inc.](/wiki/Securian_Financial_Group_Inc. "Securian Financial Group Inc.")[63]

The [3M Company](/wiki/3M_Company "3M Company") is often cited as one of Saint
Paul's companies, though it is located in adjacent
[Maplewood](/wiki/Maplewood,_Minnesota "Maplewood, Minnesota"). 3M employs
16,000 people throughout Minnesota.[64] [St. Jude
Medical](/wiki/St._Jude_Medical "St. Jude Medical"), a manufacturer of medical
devices, is directly across the northern border of Saint Paul in [Little
Canada](/wiki/Little_Canada,_Minnesota "Little Canada, Minnesota"),[65] though
the company's address is listed in Saint Paul.[66]

The city was home to the [Ford Motor Company](/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company "Ford
Motor Company")'s [Twin Cities Assembly
Plant](/wiki/Twin_Cities_Assembly_Plant "Twin Cities Assembly Plant"), which
opened in 1924 and closed at the end of 2011. The plant was in [Highland
Park](/wiki/Highland_Park,_Saint_Paul "Highland Park, Saint Paul") on the
Mississippi River, adjacent to [Lock and Dam No. 1, Mississippi
River](/wiki/Lock_and_Dam_No._1,_Mississippi_River "Lock and Dam No. 1,
Mississippi River"), which generates hydroelectric power.[67] The site is now
being cleared of all buildings and tested for contamination to prepare for
redevelopment.[68]

The city of Saint Paul has financed city development by use of [tax increment
financing (TIF)](/wiki/Tax_increment_financing "Tax increment financing"). In
2018, the city had 55 TIF districts. Some projects that have benefited from
TIF funding include the [St. Paul Saints stadium](/wiki/CHS_Field "CHS
Field"), as well as building [affordable housing](/wiki/Affordable_housing
"Affordable housing") along the Twin Cities [Metro Green
Line](/wiki/Metro_Green_Line_\(Minnesota\) "Metro Green Line
\(Minnesota\)").[69]

##
Culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Paul,_Minnesota&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Culture")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Comoplant.jpg/220px-
Comoplant.jpg)](/wiki/File:Comoplant.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Comoplant.jpg "Enlarge")

[Como Park Zoo and Conservatory](/wiki/Como_Park_Zoo_and_Conservatory "Como
Park Zoo and Conservatory") is a free public greenhouse and urban zoo open
year-round.

In winter months, Saint Paul hosts the [Saint Paul Winter
Carnival](/wiki/Saint_Paul_Winter_Carnival "Saint Paul Winter Carnival"), a
tradition that began in 1886 when a New York reporter called Saint Paul
"another [Siberia](/wiki/Siberia "Siberia")." Attended by 350,000 visitors
annually, the event showcases [ice sculpting](/wiki/Ice_sculpture "Ice
sculpture"), an annual [treasure
hunt](/wiki/Saint_Paul_Winter_Carnival#Medallion_Hunt "Saint Paul Winter
Carnival"), winter food, activities, and an ice palace.[70] The [Como Zoo and
Conservatory](/wiki/Como_Zoo_and_Conservatory "Como Zoo and Conservatory") and
adjoining Japanese Garden are popular year-round. The historic [Landmark
Center](/wiki/Landmark_Center_\(St._Paul\) "Landmark Center \(St. Paul\)") in
downtown Saint Paul hosts cultural and arts organizations. The city's notable
recreation locations include [Indian Mounds
Park](/wiki/Indian_Mounds_Park_\(Saint_Paul,_Minnesota\) "Indian Mounds Park
\(Saint Paul, Minnesota\)"), Battle Creek Regional Park, Harriet Island
Regional Park, [Highland Park](/wiki/Highland_Park,_Saint_Paul "Highland Park,
Saint Paul"), the [Wabasha Street Caves](/wiki/Wabasha_Street_Caves "Wabasha
Street Caves"), [Lake Como](/wiki/Lake_Como_\(Minnesota\) "Lake Como
\(Minnesota\)"), [Lake Phalen](/wiki/Lake_Phalen "Lake Phalen"), and [Rice
Park](/wiki/Rice_Park "Rice Park"), as well as several areas abutting the
[Mississippi River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River"). The [Irish
Fair of Minnesota](/wiki/History_of_the_Irish_in_Saint_Paul "History of the
Irish in Saint Paul") is also held annually at the [Harriet Island
Pavilion](/wiki/Harriet_Island_Pavilion "Harriet Island Pavilion") area. And
the country's largest Hmong American sports festival, the Freedom Festival, is
held the first weekend of July at McMurray Field near Como Park.

The city is associated with the [Minnesota State
Fair](/wiki/Minnesota_State_Fair "Minnesota State Fair") in nearby [Falcon
Heights](/wiki/Falcon_Heights,_Minnesota "Falcon Heights, Minnesota") just
west of Saint Paul's Como Park neighborhood and southeast of the [University
of Minnesota](/wiki/University_of_Minnesota "University of Minnesota") Saint
Paul Campus. Though [Fort Snelling](/wiki/Fort_Snelling "Fort Snelling") is on
the Minneapolis side of the Mississippi River bluff, the area including [Fort
Snelling State Park](/wiki/Fort_Snelling_State_Park "Fort Snelling State
Park") and [Pike Island](/wiki/Pike_Island "Pike Island") is managed by the
[Minnesota Department of Natural
Resources](/wiki/Minnesota_Department_of_Natural_Resources "Minnesota
Department of Natural Resources") headquartered in the city.[71]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Minnesota_Centennial_Showboat_at_night%2C_October_2013.jpg/220px-
Minnesota_Centennial_Showboat_at_night%2C_October_2013.jpg)](/wiki/File:Minnesota_Centennial_Showboat_at_night,_October_2013.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Minnesota_Centennial_Showboat_at_night,_October_2013.jpg
"Enlarge")

The [Minnesota Centennial Showboat](/wiki/Minnesota_Centennial_Showboat
"Minnesota Centennial Showboat") was anchored in the Mississippi River along
Harriet Island.

Saint Paul is the birthplace of [cartoonist](/wiki/Cartoonist "Cartoonist")
[Charles M. Schulz](/wiki/Charles_M._Schulz "Charles M. Schulz")
(_[Peanuts](/wiki/Peanuts "Peanuts")_), who lived in Merriam Park from infancy
until 1960.[72] Schulz's [Snoopy](/wiki/Snoopy "Snoopy") cartoon inspired
giant, decorated _Peanuts_ sculptures around the city, a Chamber of Commerce
promotion in the late 1990s.[73] Other notable residents include writer [F.
Scott Fitzgerald](/wiki/F._Scott_Fitzgerald "F. Scott Fitzgerald"), playwright
[August Wilson](/wiki/August_Wilson "August Wilson"), who premiered many of
the ten plays in his [Pittsburgh
Cycle](/wiki/August_Wilson#The_Pittsburgh_Cycle "August Wilson") at the local
Penumbra Theater, painter LeRoy Neiman, and photographer John Vachon.[74]

The [Ordway Center for the Performing
Arts](/wiki/Ordway_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts "Ordway Center for the
Performing Arts") hosts theater productions and the [Minnesota
Opera](/wiki/Minnesota_Opera "Minnesota Opera") is a founding tenant.[75]
[RiverCentre](/wiki/RiverCentre "RiverCentre"), attached to [Xcel Energy
Center](/wiki/Xcel_Energy_Center "Xcel Energy Center"), serves as the city's
convention center. The city has contributed to the [music of
Minnesota](/wiki/Music_of_Minnesota "Music of Minnesota") and the Twin Cities
music scene through various venues. Great jazz musicians have passed through
the influential [Artists' Quarter](/wiki/Artists%27_Quarter "Artists'
Quarter"), first established in the 1970s in [Whittier,
Minneapolis](/wiki/Whittier,_Minneapolis "Whittier, Minneapolis"), and moved
to downtown Saint Paul in 1994.[76] Artists' Quarter also hosts the Soapboxing
Poetry Slam, home of the 2009 [National Poetry
Slam](/wiki/National_Poetry_Slam "National Poetry Slam") Champions. At The
Black Dog, in Lowertown, many French or European jazz musicians (Evan Parker,
Tony Hymas, Benoît Delbecq, François Corneloup...) have met Twin Cities
musicians and started new groups touring in Europe. Groups and performers such
as Fantastic Merlins, Dean Magraw/Davu Seru, Merciless Ghosts, and [Willie
Murphy](/wiki/Willie_Murphy_\(musician\) "Willie Murphy \(musician\)") are
regulars. The [Turf Club](/wiki/Turf_Club_\(venue\) "Turf Club \(venue\)") in
Midway has been a music scene landmark since the 1940s.[77] Saint Paul is also
the home base of the internationally acclaimed [Rose
Ensemble](/wiki/Rose_Ensemble "Rose Ensemble").[78] As an Irish stronghold,
the city boasts popular Irish pubs with live music, such as Shamrocks, The
Dubliner, and O'Gara's. The internationally acclaimed [Saint Paul Chamber
Orchestra](/wiki/Saint_Paul_Chamber_Orchestra "Saint Paul Chamber Orchestra")
is the nation's only full-time professional chamber orchestra.[79] The
[Minnesota Centennial Showboat](/wiki/Minnesota_Centennial_Showboat "Minnesota
Centennial Showboat") on the Mississippi River began in 1958 with Minnesota's
first centennial celebration.[80]

Saint Paul hosts a number of museums, including the University of Minnesota's
Goldstein Museum of Design,[81] the [Minnesota Children's
Museum](/wiki/Minnesota_Children%27s_Museum "Minnesota Children's
Museum"),[82] the Schubert Club Museum of Musical Instruments,[83][84] the
[Minnesota Museum of American Art](/wiki/Minnesota_Museum_of_American_Art
"Minnesota Museum of American Art"),[85][86] the Traces Center for History and
Culture,[87] the [Minnesota History Center](/wiki/Minnesota_History_Center
"Minnesota History Center"), the [Alexander Ramsey](/wiki/Alexander_Ramsey
"Alexander Ramsey") House, the [James J. Hill House](/wiki/James_J._Hill_House
"James J. Hill House"), the [Minnesota Transportation
Museum](/wiki/Minnesota_Transportation_Museum "Minnesota Transportation
Museum"), the [Science Museum of Minnesota](/wiki/Science_Museum_of_Minnesota
"Science Museum of Minnesota"), and The Twin City Model Railroad Museum.

##
Sports[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Paul,_Minnesota&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Sports")]

Main articles: [Sports in Minneapolis–Saint
Paul](/wiki/Sports_in_Minneapolis%E2%80%93Saint_Paul "Sports in
Minneapolis–Saint Paul") and [Sports in Minnesota](/wiki/Sports_in_Minnesota
"Sports in Minnesota")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/2006_WCHA_Final_Five.jpg/220px-2006_WCHA_Final_Five.jpg)](/wiki/File:2006_WCHA_Final_Five.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2006_WCHA_Final_Five.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Xcel Energy Center](/wiki/Xcel_Energy_Center "Xcel Energy Center") hosts
hockey, other professional sports, concerts, and other events.

The Saint Paul division of Parks and Recreation runs over 1,500 organized
sports teams.[88] In addition, the Parks and Recreation department is
responsible for 160 parks and 41 recreation centers.[89]

Saint Paul hosts a number of professional, semi-professional, and amateur
sports teams. The [Minnesota Wild](/wiki/Minnesota_Wild "Minnesota Wild")[9]
play their home games in downtown Saint Paul's [Xcel Energy
Center](/wiki/Xcel_Energy_Center "Xcel Energy Center"), which opened in 2000.
The Wild brought the NHL back to Minnesota for the first time since 1993, when
the [Minnesota North Stars](/wiki/Minnesota_North_Stars "Minnesota North
Stars") left the state for [Dallas, Texas](/wiki/Dallas,_Texas "Dallas,
Texas").[9] (The [World Hockey Association](/wiki/World_Hockey_Association
"World Hockey Association")'s [Minnesota Fighting
Saints](/wiki/Minnesota_Fighting_Saints "Minnesota Fighting Saints") played in
Saint Paul from 1972 to 1977.) Citing the history of hockey in the Twin Cities
and teams at all levels, _[Sports Illustrated](/wiki/Sports_Illustrated
"Sports Illustrated")_ called Saint Paul the new [Hockeytown
U.S.A.](/wiki/Hockeytown "Hockeytown") in 2007.[90]

The Xcel Energy Center, a multipurpose entertainment and sports venue, can
host concerts and accommodate nearly all sporting events. It occupies the site
of the demolished [Saint Paul Civic Center](/wiki/Saint_Paul_Civic_Center
"Saint Paul Civic Center"). The Xcel Energy Center hosts the [Minnesota high
school boys hockey](/wiki/Minnesota_high_school_boys_hockey "Minnesota high
school boys hockey") tournament, the Minnesota high school girls' volleyball
tournament, and concerts throughout the year. In 2004, it was named the best
overall sports venue in the US by [ESPN](/wiki/ESPN "ESPN").[91]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/CJ_silks_August.jpg/150px-
CJ_silks_August.jpg)](/wiki/File:CJ_silks_August.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:CJ_silks_August.jpg "Enlarge")

Two [Circus Juventas](/wiki/Circus_Juventas "Circus Juventas") students on
[silks](/wiki/Aerial_silk "Aerial silk")

The [St. Paul Saints](/wiki/St._Paul_Saints "St. Paul Saints") is the city's
independent league baseball team. There have been several different teams
called the Saints over the years. Founded in 1884, they were shut down in 1961
after the [Minnesota Twins](/wiki/Minnesota_Twins "Minnesota Twins") moved to
[Bloomington](/wiki/Bloomington,_Minnesota "Bloomington, Minnesota"). The St.
Paul Saints were brought back in 1993 as an independent baseball team in the
[Northern League](/wiki/Northern_League_\(baseball,_1993%E2%80%932010\)
"Northern League \(baseball, 1993–2010\)"), moving to the [American
Association](/wiki/American_Association_of_Independent_Professional_Baseball
"American Association of Independent Professional Baseball") in 2006. Their
home games are played at the open-air [CHS Field](/wiki/CHS_Field "CHS Field")
in downtown's [Lowertown Historic
District](/wiki/Lowertown_Historic_District_\(Saint_Paul,_Minnesota\)
"Lowertown Historic District \(Saint Paul, Minnesota\)").[92] Four noted Major
League All-Star baseball players are natives of Saint Paul: Hall of Fame
outfielder [Dave Winfield](/wiki/Dave_Winfield "Dave Winfield"), Hall of Fame
infielder [Paul Molitor](/wiki/Paul_Molitor "Paul Molitor"), pitcher [Jack
Morris](/wiki/Jack_Morris "Jack Morris"), and first baseman [Joe
Mauer](/wiki/Joe_Mauer "Joe Mauer"). The all-black [St. Paul Colored
Gophers](/wiki/St._Paul_Colored_Gophers "St. Paul Colored Gophers") played
four seasons in Saint Paul from 1907 to 1911.[93]

The [St. Paul Twin Stars](/wiki/St._Paul_Twin_Stars "St. Paul Twin Stars") of
the [National Premier Soccer League](/wiki/National_Premier_Soccer_League
"National Premier Soccer League") play their home games at Macalester
Stadium.[94] The first [curling](/wiki/Curling "Curling") club in Saint Paul
was founded in 1888. The current club, the [St. Paul Curling
Club](/wiki/St._Paul_Curling_Club "St. Paul Curling Club"), was founded in
1912 and is the largest curling club in the United States.[95] The [Minnesota
RollerGirls](/wiki/Minnesota_RollerGirls "Minnesota RollerGirls") are a flat-
track [roller derby](/wiki/Roller_derby "Roller derby") league based in the
[Roy Wilkins Auditorium](/wiki/Roy_Wilkins_Auditorium "Roy Wilkins
Auditorium"). Minnesota's oldest athletic organization, the [Minnesota Boat
Club](/wiki/Minnesota_Boat_Club_Boathouse_on_Raspberry_Island "Minnesota Boat
Club Boathouse on Raspberry Island"), resides in the Mississippi River on
[Raspberry Island](/wiki/Raspberry_Island_\(Minnesota\) "Raspberry Island
\(Minnesota\)").[96] Saint Paul is also home to [Circus
Juventas](/wiki/Circus_Juventas "Circus Juventas"), the largest [circus
arts](/wiki/Circus_arts "Circus arts") school in [North
America](/wiki/North_America "North America").[97]

On March 25, 2015, [Major League Soccer](/wiki/Major_League_Soccer "Major
League Soccer") announced that it had awarded its 23rd MLS franchise to
[Minnesota United FC](/wiki/Minnesota_United_FC "Minnesota United FC"), a team
from the lower-level [North American Soccer
League](/wiki/North_American_Soccer_League "North American Soccer League").
[Bill McGuire](/wiki/William_W._McGuire "William W. McGuire") and his
ownership group, which includes [Jim Pohlad](/wiki/Jim_Pohlad "Jim Pohlad") of
the [Minnesota Twins](/wiki/Minnesota_Twins "Minnesota Twins"), [Glen
Taylor](/wiki/Glen_Taylor "Glen Taylor") of the [Minnesota
Timberwolves](/wiki/Minnesota_Timberwolves "Minnesota Timberwolves"), former
[Minnesota Wild](/wiki/Minnesota_Wild "Minnesota Wild") investor Glen Nelson,
and his daughter Wendy Carlson Nelson of the [Carlson](/wiki/Carlson_Companies
"Carlson Companies") hospitality company, had intended to build a privately
financed [soccer-specific stadium](/wiki/Soccer-specific_stadium "Soccer-
specific stadium") in [Downtown Minneapolis](/wiki/Downtown_Minneapolis
"Downtown Minneapolis") near the Minneapolis Farmer's Market, but their plan
was met with heavy opposition from Minneapolis Mayor [Betsy
Hodges](/wiki/Betsy_Hodges "Betsy Hodges"), who said her city was suffering
from "stadium fatigue" after building three stadiums, for the [Minnesota
Twins](/wiki/Minnesota_Twins "Minnesota Twins"), [Minnesota
Vikings](/wiki/Minnesota_Vikings "Minnesota Vikings") and the [Minnesota
Golden Gophers](/wiki/Minnesota_Golden_Gophers "Minnesota Golden Gophers"),
within a six-year span.[98] On July 1, 2015, after failing to reach an
agreement with the city of Minneapolis, McGuire and his partners turned their
focus to Saint Paul.[99]

On October 23, 2015, Bill McGuire of Minnesota United FC and Saint Paul Mayor
[Chris Coleman](/wiki/Chris_Coleman_\(politician\) "Chris Coleman
\(politician\)") announced that a privately financed soccer-specific stadium
would be built on the vacant [Metro Transit](/wiki/Metro_Transit_\(Minnesota\)
"Metro Transit \(Minnesota\)") bus barn site in Saint Paul's Midway
neighborhood near the intersection of [Snelling
Avenue](/wiki/Minnesota_State_Highway_51 "Minnesota State Highway 51") and
[University Avenue](/wiki/University_Avenue_\(Minneapolis-Saint_Paul\)
"University Avenue \(Minneapolis-Saint Paul\)"). It is midway between downtown
Saint Paul and downtown Minneapolis. The stadium will open in 2019 and seat
19,400. The team will play in the MLS in 2017.[100]

The [Timberwolves](/wiki/Minnesota_Timberwolves "Minnesota Timberwolves"),
[Twins](/wiki/Minnesota_Twins "Minnesota Twins"),
[Vikings](/wiki/Minnesota_Vikings "Minnesota Vikings"), and
[Lynx](/wiki/Minnesota_Lynx "Minnesota Lynx") all play in
[Minneapolis](/wiki/Minneapolis "Minneapolis").[101]

## Government and
politics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Paul,_Minnesota&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Government and politics")]

Main articles: [Government and politics in Saint Paul,
Minnesota](/wiki/Government_and_politics_in_Saint_Paul,_Minnesota "Government
and politics in Saint Paul, Minnesota") and [List of mayors of Saint Paul,
Minnesota](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Saint_Paul,_Minnesota "List of mayors of
Saint Paul, Minnesota")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Minnesota_State_Capitol.jpg/220px-
Minnesota_State_Capitol.jpg)](/wiki/File:Minnesota_State_Capitol.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Minnesota_State_Capitol.jpg "Enlarge")

[Minnesota State Capitol](/wiki/Minnesota_State_Capitol "Minnesota State
Capitol")

Saint Paul has a variation of the [strong mayor-council](/wiki/Mayor-
council_government#Strong-mayor_form "Mayor-council government") form of
government.[104] The mayor is the [chief executive](/wiki/Chief_executive
"Chief executive") and [chief administrative
officer](/wiki/Chief_administrative_officer "Chief administrative officer")
for the city and the seven-member city council is the legislative
body.[105][106] The mayor is elected by the entire city, while members of the
city council are elected from seven different geographic wards of
approximately equal population.[107][108] Both the mayor and council members
serve four-year terms.[109] The [current
mayor](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Saint_Paul,_Minnesota "List of mayors of Saint
Paul, Minnesota") is [Melvin Carter](/wiki/Melvin_Carter_\(politician\)
"Melvin Carter \(politician\)") ([DFL](/wiki/Minnesota_Democratic-Farmer-
Labor_Party "Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party")). Carter is Saint
Paul's first African-American mayor. Aside from Norm Coleman, who became a
Republican during his second term, Saint Paul has not elected a Republican
mayor since 1952.[110]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Saint_Paul_City_Hall.jpg/220px-
Saint_Paul_City_Hall.jpg)](/wiki/File:Saint_Paul_City_Hall.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Saint_Paul_City_Hall.jpg "Enlarge")

[Saint Paul City Hall and Ramsey County
Courthouse](/wiki/Saint_Paul_City_Hall_and_Ramsey_County_Courthouse "Saint
Paul City Hall and Ramsey County Courthouse")

The city is also the county seat of [Ramsey
County](/wiki/Ramsey_County,_Minnesota "Ramsey County, Minnesota"), named for
[Alexander Ramsey](/wiki/Alexander_Ramsey "Alexander Ramsey"), the state's
first governor. The county once spanned much of the present-day metropolitan
area and was originally to be named Saint Paul County after the city. Today it
is geographically the smallest county and the most densely populated.[6]
Ramsey is the only home rule county in Minnesota; the seven-member Board of
Commissioners appoints a county manager whose office is in the combination
city hall/county courthouse along with the Minnesota Second Judicial
Courts.[111][112] The nearby Law Enforcement Center houses the Ramsey County
Sheriff's office.

### State and
federal[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Paul,_Minnesota&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: State and federal")]

See also: [Minnesota Legislature](/wiki/Minnesota_Legislature "Minnesota
Legislature") and [Politics of Minnesota § Federal
representation](/wiki/Politics_of_Minnesota#Federal_representation "Politics
of Minnesota")

Saint Paul is the capital of the state of Minnesota. The city hosts the
capitol building, designed by Saint Paul resident [Cass
Gilbert](/wiki/Cass_Gilbert "Cass Gilbert"), and the
[House](/wiki/Minnesota_House_of_Representatives "Minnesota House of
Representatives") and [Senate](/wiki/Minnesota_Senate "Minnesota Senate")
office buildings. The [Minnesota Governor's
Residence](/wiki/Minnesota_Governor%27s_Residence "Minnesota Governor's
Residence"), which is used for some state functions, is on [Summit
Avenue](/wiki/Summit_Avenue_\(St._Paul\) "Summit Avenue \(St. Paul\)"). The
[Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party](/wiki/Minnesota_Democratic-Farmer-
Labor_Party "Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party") (affiliated with the
[Democratic Party](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party
\(United States\)")) is headquartered in Saint Paul. Numerous state
departments and services are also headquartered in Saint Paul, such as the
[Minnesota Department of Natural
Resources](/wiki/Minnesota_Department_of_Natural_Resources "Minnesota
Department of Natural Resources").

The city is split into four Minnesota Senate districts (64, 65, 66 and 67) and
eight Minnesota House of Representatives districts (64A, 64B, 65A, 65B, 66A,
66B, 67A and 67B), all of which are held by Democrats.[113][114]

Saint Paul is the heart of [Minnesota's 4th congressional
district](/wiki/Minnesota%27s_4th_congressional_district "Minnesota's 4th
congressional district"), represented by Democrat [Betty
McCollum](/wiki/Betty_McCollum "Betty McCollum"). The district has been in DFL
hands without interruption since 1949. Minnesota is represented in the US
[Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") by Democrat [Amy
Klobuchar](/wiki/Amy_Klobuchar "Amy Klobuchar"), a former [Hennepin
County](/wiki/Hennepin_County "Hennepin County") Attorney, and Democrat [Tina
Smith](/wiki/Tina_Smith "Tina Smith"), former Lieutenant Governor of
Minnesota.

##
Education[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Paul,_Minnesota&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Education")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/1930s_HU_STUDENTS.jpg/220px-1930s_HU_STUDENTS.jpg)](/wiki/File:1930s_HU_STUDENTS.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1930s_HU_STUDENTS.jpg "Enlarge")

1930s-era students at [Hamline University](/wiki/Hamline_University "Hamline
University") taking finals

Main article: [Education in Saint Paul,
Minnesota](/wiki/Education_in_Saint_Paul,_Minnesota "Education in Saint Paul,
Minnesota")

Saint Paul is second in the United States in the number of higher education
institutions per capita.[115] Higher education institutions that call Saint
Paul home include three public and eight private colleges and universities and
five post-secondary institutions. Well-known colleges and universities include
the [Saint Catherine University](/wiki/Saint_Catherine_University "Saint
Catherine University"), [Concordia
University](/wiki/Concordia_University,_Saint_Paul "Concordia University,
Saint Paul"), [Hamline University](/wiki/Hamline_University "Hamline
University"), [Macalester College](/wiki/Macalester_College "Macalester
College"), and the [University of St.
Thomas](/wiki/University_of_St._Thomas_\(Minnesota\) "University of St. Thomas
\(Minnesota\)"). [Metropolitan State
University](/wiki/Metropolitan_State_University "Metropolitan State
University") and [Saint Paul College](/wiki/Saint_Paul_College "Saint Paul
College"), which focus on non-traditional students, are based in Saint Paul,
as well as a law school, [Mitchell Hamline School of
Law](/wiki/Mitchell_Hamline_School_of_Law "Mitchell Hamline School of
Law").[116]

The [Saint Paul Public Schools](/wiki/Saint_Paul_Public_Schools "Saint Paul
Public Schools") district is the state's largest school district and serves
approximately 39,000 students. The district is extremely diverse with students
from families speaking 90 different languages, although only five languages
are used for most school communication: English, Spanish,
[Hmong](/wiki/Hmong_language "Hmong language"), Karen, and
[Somali](/wiki/Somali_language "Somali language"). The district runs 82
different schools, including 52 [elementary schools](/wiki/Elementary_school
"Elementary school"), twelve [middle schools](/wiki/Middle_school "Middle
school"), seven [high schools](/wiki/High_school_\(North_America\) "High
school \(North America\)"), ten [alternative schools](/wiki/Alternative_school
"Alternative school"), and one [special education](/wiki/Special_education
"Special education") school, employing over 6,500 teachers and staff. The
school district also oversees community education programs for pre-K and adult
learners, including Early Childhood Family Education, [GED](/wiki/GED "GED")
Diploma, language programs, and various learning opportunities for community
members of all ages. In 2006, Saint Paul Public Schools celebrated its 150th
anniversary.[117] Some students attend public schools in other school
districts chosen by their families under Minnesota's open enrollment
statute.[118]

A variety of [K-12](/wiki/K%E2%80%9312_\(education\) "K–12 \(education\)")
[private](/wiki/Private_school "Private school"),
[parochial](/wiki/Parochial_school "Parochial school"), and public [charter
schools](/wiki/Charter_school "Charter school") are also represented in the
city. In 1992, Saint Paul became the first city in the US to sponsor and open
a charter school, now found in most states across the nation.[119] Saint Paul
is currently home to 21 charter schools as well as 38 private schools.[120]
The [Saint Paul Public Library](/wiki/Saint_Paul_Public_Library "Saint Paul
Public Library") system includes a Central Library and twelve branch
locations.[121]

##
Media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Paul,_Minnesota&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Media")]

Main article: [Media in the Twin Cities](/wiki/Media_in_the_Twin_Cities "Media
in the Twin Cities")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Minnesota_Public_Radio_Ticker_Saint_Paul_15188440793_e36b211583_o.jpg/220px-
Minnesota_Public_Radio_Ticker_Saint_Paul_15188440793_e36b211583_o.jpg)](/wiki/File:Minnesota_Public_Radio_Ticker_Saint_Paul_15188440793_e36b211583_o.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Minnesota_Public_Radio_Ticker_Saint_Paul_15188440793_e36b211583_o.jpg
"Enlarge")

Minnesota Public Radio headquarters in downtown Saint Paul

Residents of Saint Paul can receive 10 broadcast television stations, five of
which broadcast from within Saint Paul. One daily newspaper, the _[St. Paul
Pioneer Press](/wiki/St._Paul_Pioneer_Press "St. Paul Pioneer Press")_ , two
weekly neighborhood newspapers, the _[East Side Review](/wiki/East_Side_Review
"East Side Review")_ and _[City Pages](/wiki/City_Pages "City Pages")_ (owned
by [The Star Tribune Company](/wiki/Star_Tribune "Star Tribune")), and several
monthly or semimonthly neighborhood papers serve the city. Several media
outlets based in neighboring Minneapolis also serve the Saint Paul community,
including the _[Star Tribune](/wiki/Star_Tribune "Star Tribune")_. Saint Paul
is home to [Minnesota Public Radio](/wiki/Minnesota_Public_Radio "Minnesota
Public Radio"), a three-format system that broadcasts on nearly 40
stations[122] around the Midwest. MPR locally delivers news and information,
classical, and The Current (which plays a wide variety of music). The station
has 110,000 regional members and more than 800,000 listeners each week
throughout the Upper Midwest, the largest audience of any regional public
radio network.[123] Also operating as part of [American Public
Media](/wiki/American_Public_Media "American Public Media"), MPR's programming
reaches five million listeners, most notably through _[Live from
Here](/wiki/Live_from_Here "Live from Here")_ , hosted by [Chris
Thile](/wiki/Chris_Thile "Chris Thile") (previously known as _[A Prairie Home
Companion](/wiki/A_Prairie_Home_Companion "A Prairie Home Companion")_ ,
hosted by [Garrison Keillor](/wiki/Garrison_Keillor "Garrison Keillor"), who
also lives in the city).[123] The [Fitzgerald
Theater](/wiki/Fitzgerald_Theater "Fitzgerald Theater"), renamed in 1994 for
Saint Paul native and novelist [F. Scott Fitzgerald](/wiki/F._Scott_Fitzgerald
"F. Scott Fitzgerald"), is home to the show.[124]

Residents use [Interstate 35E](/wiki/Interstate_35E_\(Minnesota\) "Interstate
35E \(Minnesota\)") running north-south and [Interstate
94](/wiki/Interstate_94 "Interstate 94") running east-west. Trunk highways
include [U.S. Highway 52](/wiki/U.S._Route_52_in_Minnesota "U.S. Route 52 in
Minnesota"), [Minnesota State Highway 280](/wiki/Minnesota_State_Highway_280
"Minnesota State Highway 280"), and [Minnesota State Highway
5](/wiki/Minnesota_State_Highway_5 "Minnesota State Highway 5"). Saint Paul
has several unique roads such as [Ayd Mill Road](/wiki/Ayd_Mill_Road "Ayd Mill
Road"), Phalen Boulevard and [Shepard Road/Warner
Road](/wiki/Shepard_Road/Warner_Road "Shepard Road/Warner Road"), which
diagonally follow particular geographic features in the city. Biking is also
gaining popularity, due to the creation of more paved [bike
lanes](/wiki/Segregated_cycle_facilities "Segregated cycle facilities") that
connect to other bike routes throughout the [metropolitan
area](/wiki/Metropolitan_area "Metropolitan area")[125] and the creation of
[Nice Ride Minnesota](/wiki/Nice_Ride_Minnesota "Nice Ride Minnesota"), a
seasonally operated nonprofit bicycle sharing and rental system that has over
1,550 bicycles and 170 stations in both Minneapolis and Saint Paul.[126]
Downtown Saint Paul has a five-mile (8 km) enclosed [skyway](/wiki/Skyway
"Skyway") system over twenty-five city blocks.[127] The 563-mile (906 km)
[Avenue of the Saints](/wiki/Avenue_of_the_Saints "Avenue of the Saints")
connects Saint Paul with [Saint Louis](/wiki/St._Louis,_Missouri "St. Louis,
Missouri"), [Missouri](/wiki/Missouri "Missouri").

The layout of city streets and roads has often drawn complaints. While he was
[Governor of Minnesota](/wiki/Governor_of_Minnesota "Governor of Minnesota"),
[Jesse Ventura](/wiki/Jesse_Ventura "Jesse Ventura") appeared on the _[Late
Show with David Letterman](/wiki/Late_Show_with_David_Letterman "Late Show
with David Letterman")_ ,[128] and remarked that the streets were designed by
"drunken Irishmen".[129] He later apologized, though people had been
complaining about the fractured grid system for more than a century by that
point.[129] Some of the city's road design is the result of the curve of the
Mississippi River, hilly topography, conflicts between developers of different
neighborhoods in the early city, and grand plans only half-realized. Outside
of downtown, the roads are less confusing, but most roads are named, rather
than numbered, increasing the difficulty for non-natives to navigate.[130]

Transit \(Minnesota\)")

[Metro Transit](/wiki/Metro_Transit_\(Minnesota\) "Metro Transit
\(Minnesota\)") provides bus service and light rail in the Minneapolis–Saint
Paul area. The [METRO Green Line](/wiki/METRO_Green_Line "METRO Green Line")
is an 11-mile (18 km) [light rail](/wiki/Light_rail "Light rail") line that
connects downtown Saint Paul to downtown Minneapolis with 14 stations in Saint
Paul. The Green Line runs west along [University
Avenue](/wiki/University_Avenue_\(Minneapolis-St._Paul\) "University Avenue
\(Minneapolis-St. Paul\)"), through the [University of
Minnesota](/wiki/University_of_Minnesota "University of Minnesota") campus,
until it links up and then shares stations with the [METRO Blue
Line](/wiki/Blue_Line_\(Minnesota\) "Blue Line \(Minnesota\)") in downtown
Minneapolis. Construction began in November 2010 and the line began service on
June 14, 2014.[131] Roughly 45,000 people rode on the first day; an average
28,000 riders are expected per day.[132]

[Metro Transit](/wiki/Metro_Transit_\(Minnesota\) "Metro Transit
\(Minnesota\)") opened the [METRO A Line](/wiki/A_Line_\(Minnesota\) "A Line
\(Minnesota\)"), Minneapolis–Saint Paul's first arterial [bus rapid
transit](/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit "Bus rapid transit") line, along [Snelling
Avenue](/wiki/Snelling_Avenue "Snelling Avenue") and Ford Parkway. The A Line
connects the [METRO Blue Line](/wiki/Metro_Blue_Line_\(Minnesota\) "Metro Blue
Line \(Minnesota\)") at [46th Street
station](/wiki/46th_Street_\(Metro_Transit_station\) "46th Street \(Metro
Transit station\)") to [Rosedale Center](/wiki/Rosedale_Center "Rosedale
Center") with a connection at the [Green
Line](/wiki/Metro_Green_Line_\(Minnesota\) "Metro Green Line \(Minnesota\)")
[Snelling Avenue station](/wiki/Snelling_Avenue_\(Metro_Transit_station\)
"Snelling Avenue \(Metro Transit station\)"). The A Line is the first in a
series of planned arterial bus rapid transit lines and is set to open in early
2016.[133]

###
Railroad[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Paul,_Minnesota&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Railroad")]

[Amtrak](/wiki/Amtrak "Amtrak")'s _[Empire Builder](/wiki/Empire_Builder
"Empire Builder")_ between Chicago and Seattle stops once daily in each
direction at the newly renovated [Saint Paul Union
Station](/wiki/Saint_Paul_Union_Station "Saint Paul Union Station").[134]
Ridership on the train is increasing, about 6% from 2005 to over 505,000 in
fiscal year 2007.[135] Increased ridership has prompted southern Minnesota
leaders to plan for an expansion of Amtrak's service in the area.[135] Saint
Paul is the site of the Pig's Eye Yard, a major freight [classification
yard](/wiki/Classification_yard "Classification yard") for [Canadian Pacific
Railway](/wiki/Canadian_Pacific_Railway "Canadian Pacific Railway").[136] As
of 2003, the yard handled over 1,000 freight cars per day.[136] Both [Union
Pacific](/wiki/Union_Pacific_Railroad "Union Pacific Railroad") and
[Burlington Northern Santa Fe](/wiki/BNSF_Railway "BNSF Railway") run trains
through the yard, though they are not classified at Pig's Eye.[136] Burlington
Northern Santa Fe operates the large Northtown Yard in Minneapolis, which
handles about 600 cars per day.[137] There are several other small yards
located around the city.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/20080312-StPaulDowntownAirport.jpg/220px-20080312-StPaulDowntownAirport.jpg)](/wiki/File:20080312-StPaulDowntownAirport.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:20080312-StPaulDowntownAirport.jpg "Enlarge")

Saint Paul Downtown Airport (Holman Field)

###
Airports[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Paul,_Minnesota&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Airports")]

See also: [St. Paul Downtown Airport](/wiki/St._Paul_Downtown_Airport "St.
Paul Downtown Airport")

Saint Paul is served by the [Minneapolis–Saint Paul International
Airport](/wiki/Minneapolis%E2%80%93Saint_Paul_International_Airport
"Minneapolis–Saint Paul International Airport") (MSP), which sits on 3,400
acres (14 km2)[138] southwest of the city on the west side of the Mississippi
River between [Minnesota State Highway 5](/wiki/Minnesota_State_Highway_5
"Minnesota State Highway 5"), [Interstate 494](/wiki/Interstate_494
"Interstate 494"), [Minnesota State Highway
77](/wiki/Minnesota_State_Highway_77 "Minnesota State Highway 77"), and
[Minnesota State Highway 62](/wiki/Minnesota_State_Highway_62_\(east\)
"Minnesota State Highway 62 \(east\)"). The airport serves three
international, twelve domestic, seven charter, and four regional carriers[139]
and is a hub and home base for [Delta Air Lines](/wiki/Delta_Air_Lines "Delta
Air Lines"), [Mesaba Airlines](/wiki/Mesaba_Airlines "Mesaba Airlines") and
[Sun Country Airlines](/wiki/Sun_Country_Airlines "Sun Country
Airlines").[140] Saint Paul is also served by the [St. Paul Downtown
Airport](/wiki/St._Paul_Downtown_Airport "St. Paul Downtown Airport") located
just south of downtown, across the Mississippi River. The airport, also known
as Holman Field, is a [reliever airport](/wiki/FAA_airport_categories "FAA
airport categories") run by the [Metropolitan Airports
Commission](/wiki/Metropolitan_Airports_Commission "Metropolitan Airports
Commission"). The airport houses Minnesota's Air National Guard and is
tailored to [local
corporate](/wiki/Companies_based_in_Minneapolis%E2%80%93St._Paul "Companies
based in Minneapolis–St. Paul") aviation.[141] There are three runways that
serve about 100 resident aircraft and a flight training school. The [Holman
Field Administration Building](/wiki/Holman_Field_Administration_Building
"Holman Field Administration Building") and [Riverside
Hangar](/wiki/Riverside_Hangar "Riverside Hangar") are on the National
Register of Historic Places.[141]
